abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Capacity Building for
            Economic Management Project (CBEMP) for the Gambia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in countries with very limited public sector
            capacity, a major overhaul of public sector management
            systems on multiple fronts simultaneously is likely to
            require a programmatic approach to lending rather than a
            single investment loan. The downscaling of initiatives
            during CBEMP implementation, the additional financing and
            the extension of the closing date for the project indicate
            that the full implementation of the project initiatives
            under a single credit was unrealistic from the beginning.
            Fundamental reforms in the Government's way of doing
            business require a long term perspective. When such reforms
            are attempted under a single project, inevitably it leads to
            implementation delays and significant risks to
            sustainability due to the lack of time for the reforms to
            become entrenched. For this reason, a second CBEMP is
            currently under preparation in order to sustain and deepen
            implementation of key initiatives under the first CBEMP.
            Commitment to the project at the top levels of Government is
            a necessary but not sufficient condition for timely project
            implementation. A fully satisfactory outcome ultimately must
            have the backing of the line managers in charge of
            implementing the project's components. For CBEMP, it
            was not until there was a change in the relevant management,
            several years after the start of the project that
            substantial work on the Integrated Financial Management
            Information System (IFMIS) began in earnest. It is
            recommended that a clear and transparent mechanism be
            established in advance on how best to address instances of
            protracted lack of commitment by a beneficiary, including
            triggers for the removal of the beneficiary through project restructuring.
